PAGE 78 Minimum Wage Policy 
The Thai government’s 300 Baht minimum daily wage policy that took effect on 1 April 
2013 has created a lot of ruckus from the  whole spectrum of the business community. 
 
Prior to its implementation, the minimum da ily wage ranged from 159 Baht in Phayao 
(Northern region) to 215 Baht in Bangkok and 221 Baht in Phuket.  
 
Among major concerns include:  
 An increase in production costs without any increase in production output; 
 A shortage of skilled labor; and, 
 Multinational companies with large labor for ces are likely to consider investing in 
neighboring countries with more competitive cost structures. 
 
In response the Department of Skill Development under the Ministry of Labor, has 
announced additional training for new and non-skilled labor.  However, the wage 
increase is also an opportunity for compan ies in Thailand to further automate 
manufacturing processes.   
 
For employees,  the government,  and labor unions, the hope is that in a time of 
economic  growth (5% predicted  for 2013) and low unemployment  (0.6% at the end of 
2012), increased  income for workers will boost consumption  and force productivity  
gains and innovation.  This will then drive a more balanced,  modernized,  and 
competitive  economy  and help Thailand avoid the much‐dreaded middle‐income trap. 
Indeed, one of the commonly  stated goals of the new minimum  wage is that it will 
push Thai workers to raise their own skill levels in preparation  for increased  labor 
competition  with the opening of the ASEAN Economic  Community  on 1 January 2016. 
 
Advocates  of the policy also anticipate  that the modernization  of Thai businesses  and 
increases  in productivity  will lead to a reduction  in the level of geographical  disparity 
in Thailand, with fewer workers forced to move to Bangkok for higher wages. 
 
There are fears on the part of some employers  that increased  labor costs (the new 
minimum  wage applies to every employee  in Thailand, regardless  of age, sex, industry, 
or nationality)  will affect already struggling  SMEs and could lead to employee  layoffs 
or even force some SMEs out of business. This could, in turn, negatively  impact 
employment,  increase unskilled workers’ vulnerability,  raise the cost of living, and 
worsen poverty in the country. Many employers  fear that Thailand’s  international  and 
regional competitiveness  will be negatively  affected by increased  labor costs, which 
could trigger Thai businesses  to employ greater numbers of informal labor.  
 
Migrant workers from Thailand’s  neighbors,  particularly  Cambodia,  where the daily 
minimum  wage is barely US$2.03 and Myanmar  where the daily minimum

wage is 58 
cents, are expected to come in even greater numbers,  attracted  by higher wages. In 
fact, some Cambodian  factory owners are complaining  that they are now facing a 
labor shortage as locals move to Thailand for better wages.

[GEEF TEKST OP] 
 
PAGE 79 To obviate experiencing  anticipated  problems,  a number of Thai companies  have 
started moving their investments  to Myanmar  and Cambodia  – for the same reason as 
cited above.  To add insult to injury, a number of new investors that were eyeing 
expansion  in Asia had bypassed  Thailand altogether  and opted to set up operations  in 
Laos and Cambodia.  
 
Other Government Procedures 
Current approval process for foreign employ ees normally takes about three to six 
months which is considered too long by inte rnational food service operators.  The 
industry is clamoring for speedier and short er approval of fore ign workers by the 
government.   
 
They also would like to include in job  contracts a non-competition clause which 
prohibits a person from working for another firm in the same industry within a year 
after resignation.  When employees leave the  company, they take with them ‘guarded 
recipes’ of the bakery or restaurant. 
 The local staff shortage in the food industry can be attribute d to university graduates’ 
changing attitudes as they prefer to run the ir own businesses rather than working for 
others.

 Overview of Dutch Bakery Industry  
Introduction 
The Dutch bakery industry includes industrial  bakeries, artisan bakeries, confectionery  
and bread and pastry shops. The number of bakeries has declined the last decades. In 
1960 the Netherlands  counted more than 10,000 companies  active in the bakery 
industry, by now only 2,200 are left. This trend is still ongoing; however the average 
size of the companies  is actually increasing.  Scale is important;  therefore  the industry 
encounters  various mergers and acquisitions.  
 Companies  active in the Dutch bakery industry provide a wide range of products to 
bakers, catering outlets, supermarkets  and consumers.  These include ingredients  for 
bakeries, final products and bake off products
 to supermarkets.  The Dutch bakery 
industry is visualized  in the chain below. 
 
 
      Finished product         Intermediate  product          Semi‐finished product 
 
Trends in the Dutch market 
In 2011 Dutch consumers  spent more than € 5.1 billion (including  taxes) on bread and 
pastry, nearly as much as in 2010. Bread products accounted  for the majority of these 
expenses  (see expenditures).  Supermarkets  had the largest market share (63%) 
followed by bread and pastry shop (28%). 
 
The Dutch bakery industry shows the following  trends: 
1. Rising commodities prices:  In recent years the costs of commodities  are rising. 
As a result of shortage in the world market, procurement  costs are increasing

[GEEF TEKST OP] 
 
PAGE 81 and producers  cannot totally pass on this increment  in the selling price. This 
leads to smaller margins in the production  chain and parties are therefore  
forced to work more efficiently.   
 
2. Economies of scale: As mentioned  earlier there is a trend of scaling and merging 
and acquisitions  ongoing in the bakery industry, which is visible worldwide.  
Partially to work more efficient and to downgrade  operational  costs. In the last 
decade most of the merging and acquisitions  in the bakery industry took place in 
Europe (755) and Northern ‐America and Canada (326) (Bakkerswereld,  2012). 
Since 2006 there is a relative higher number of cross border merging and 
acquisitions  deals than before. It is expected that in the coming years there will 
be a vast increase in merging and acquisitions  from within the Asia‐Pacific 
region. This increase will be partly focused on acquisitions  in developed  
economies.   
 
3. Internationalization:  In segments  where ‘time to market’ is less crucial there is a 
trend visible where big buyers decide to buy international.  Eventually  this might 
lead to more cross‐border deals (see trend merging and acquisitions).  
 
4. Regulations:  Higher levels of quality, more laws and regulations,  certifications  
and audits lead to necessary  investments.  For small‐scale companies  these costs 
and investments  can have a substantial  influence  on the company results.  
 
5. Demand for luxury products:  There is a growing demand for luxury and 
convenience  products in the Dutch markets. Pre‐baked, packed and ready‐to‐eat 
products are getting more popular. 
 
6. Healthy and safe products:  There is a growing awareness  for products which 
focus on healthy living. Examples  are products with less salt (& fat), gluten free 
products and products focusing on a special diet. 
 
7. Changing pattern in consumption:  Consumers  tend to eat more out of home 
than they used to do a few years ago.  
 
Opportunities and threats 
As a result of the above‐mentioned  trends, companies  are confronted  with a changing 
competitive  landscape.  
 
Opportunities  
 Diet products,  using less salt, sugar free products and bread with added vitamins 
 Responsible  produced,  biological  and authentic  products 
 Out of home products 
 New products and diversification  of the product range 
 Growth expected in the bake‐off subsector

[GEEF TEKST OP] 
 
PAGE 82 Threats 
 Scaling is getting more important:  ‘eat or get eaten’ 
 The traditional  clientele is getting older 
 The diversification  in bread and pastry products at supermarkets  has influence  
on the market share of the artisan bakery 
 
Dutch presence in Thailand 
The overall presence of Dutch bakery‐related companies  in Thailand is limited with 
only a few players having entered or supplied Dutch bakery products.  At present we 
have identified  two Dutch companies  that have established  their operations  locally 
and a few companies  that have local presence with their main operations  still in the 
Netherlands.  
 
Most of those companies  are known for supplying  products,  mainly ingredients  and 
equipment,  and have set up local offices for distribution  purposes.   
 One of the most notable companies  that supplies equipment  is Rademaker BV,  a 
premier manufacturer  of bakery equipment  from the Netherlands.   Their local agency 
representation  in Thailand functions  as a distributor  and sales office. Besides their 
agency in 
Thailand they also have regional presence with sales offices and agencies in 
Singapore,  Malaysia,  Indonesia,  Taiwan, Australia and Vietnam. 
 
Another notable company that supplies ingredients  is Koninklijke Zeelandia Group 
BV, which through its subsidiaries,  engages in the development,  production,  sale, and 
distribution  of baking ingredients  for the bread and confectionery  markets. Although 
they do not have local presence,  PT Zeelandia  Indonesia  distributes  their products to 
several countries,  among others: Singapore,  Malaysia,  Vietnam, The Philippines  and 
Thailand. 
 Then there is Koniklijke FrieslandCampina BV  that supplies consumer  products such 
as dairy‐based beverages,  infant & toddler nutrition,  cheese and desserts in many 
European  countries,  Asia and Africa.
 Their products are also supplied to professional  
customers,  including cream and butter products to bakeries and catering companies.  
They are active in Thailand but have yet to expand their operations  here outside of 
their core‐business ‐ dairy.  
 
Steensma (Thailand) Co., Ltd. , is a manufacturer of preserved/candied fruits based in 
Chiang Mai.   The factory in Thailand only  produces raw materials for the parent 
company Steensma B.V. located  in the Leeuwarden, Netherlands.  Promoted by the 
Board of Investment, Steensma (Thailand) mainly produces fermented papaya and 
calabash.  These products are suitable for the  food industry, including bakery.  At 
present, Steensma (Thailand) exports 100% of their products to the Netherlands. 
 
Siam Makro

PLC  is engaged in a cash and carry wholesaling/retailing  of dry goods as 
well as fresh items with 61 stores nationwide.   It also operates an in‐store bakery shop 
in all branches.  Their in‐store bakery is a ‘side’ business with only 1.3 percent of their

PAGE 84 Business Opportunity Analysis  
The Thai bakery sector presents several bu siness opportunities which could be grouped 
as follows:   
‒ Trade opportunities;  
‒ Investment opportunities; and,  
‒ Technical cooperatio n opportunities. 
 1 Trade opportunities  1.1 Import of raw materials/ingredients 
Thailand is self-sufficient for granulated sugar and fat (butter/margarine/shortening); 
but there are still some imports of these prod ucts.  For the other bakery ingredients, the 
country is highly dependent on imports, whic h creates vast opportu nities for foreign-
based manufacturers to supply the market.   
There is great potential to sell high-grade in gredients to hotels.  For instance, Anantara 
Bakery of the hotel chain uses only high  quality ingredients imported from Europe and 
the U.S. for making breads, cakes and pastries for distribution to the food service and 
catering sectors.  Luxury hotels with in-house  bake shop number about 500 in Thailand; 
and they make freshly baked br ead and bakery products dail y for serving guests, retail 
sale and / or delivery to outside customers. 
 
To be acceptable to bakers, ‘new’ ingred ients, or new brand of ingredients needs to 
undergo a lengthy process of product testi ng.  Normally the ingredient needs to be 
tested at the client’s R&D lab  where all product quality te sts and analyses are conducted. 
The process may take months and even a year but the end-result can be rewarding. The 
brand (supplier) will be a trusted partner foreve r.  While product quality is the number 
one criterion in selecting a new supplier or br and, price is also a key factor in the final 
evaluation.  Thus the new product will have  to pass the product quality standards and 
also be competitive with other bra nds available in the market.    
 
Wheat and wheat flour While the bakery sector mainly  uses locally-milled flour, the  basic raw material which is 
wheat, is all imported. At present, wheat expor ts into Thailand originate mostly from the 
U.S., Australia, and Canada which have been  the country’s long-term trading partners 
for wheat.  Opportunities for other countries to export wheat into the country are low.   
 On the other hand, Thailand still has to import wheat flour because existing production 
volumes do not fully meet local demand.  So me 200,000 to 250,0 00 tons of wheat flour 
are imported each year worth 3 to 3.5 billion baht.  In the bakery sector, medium to 
high-grade types of wheat flour are importe d from the U.K. U.S.A., Russian Federation 
and Europe (e.g., Belgium, Germany, Fran ce, Italy, Ukraine).  Leading industrial 
bakeries, hotels and catering companies look  for high quality wheat flour used in 
various applications such as bread, pastries, and cream fillings.  This is clearly an 
opportunity for wheat flour producers overseas.

PAGE 87 1.4 Other opportunities 
Aside from the abovementioned product categor ies, the bakery sector offers a range of 
other opportunities, for instance in services (e .g., training, education) and IT solutions.  
The sector experiences shortage of skilled  manpower because new graduates prefer 
managing their own business rather than worki ng in hotels and restaurants to gain 
experience.  A solution could be training  people that have the interest, but lack proper 
educational background, in bakery schools and training centers outside the academic 
system.    Seamless interaction of production processes in the bakery industry is crucial – and an IT solution such as integrated automation syste m for bakery production processes could be 
the answer.  This would cover both softwa re and hardware that would automate the 
production process – from receipt of raw materials / ingredients to production and 
packaging to finished product shipment.  Larg e-scale industrial bakeries are known to 
already employ automated systems for the prod uction process; but a fully integrated 
system that delivers maximum quality at reduced cost may still be lacking in most 
factories.  Other IT solutions suitable for small and medium-sized businesses also have 
good prospects in the bakery sector.   
2. Investment opportunities 
Investment in the Thai bakery s ector can take several forms:  
 
‒ Acquisitions/ Joint venture/Greenfield investment 
‒ Franchising 
‒ Regional Operating Headquarters 
‒ Technical Cooperation  
 For investors who are looking for business expan sion in Southeast Asia, Thailand is at a 
vantage position.  The country enjoys a strateg ic location and serves as a gateway into 
the heart of Asia – home to what is today the largest growing economic market.   
 Political stability has increased and Th ailand’s economic momentum has strongly 
improved after severe external shocks. Howe ver, future political and commercial risks 
will largely depend on domesti c political developments and g lobal economic climate as 
Thailand’s economy remains primarily expor t-driven.  Annex 4 provides a brief 
discussion of ‘why Thailand’ could  be the best choice for investment. 
 2.1 Acquisition/Joint venture/Greenfield investment 
Given the growth potential of the Thai bakery sector and Thailand’s increasing position 
as ‘regional hub,’ Dutch strategic investo rs should consider entering into equity 
partnerships with local counterparts through  acquisition, joint venture or other 
structures.   
 
One immediate opportunity is setting up a loc al blending facility for premixes and other 
flour mixes.   The Thai bakery industry ma inly imports premixes, cake mixes and other 
flour mixes from overseas suppliers.  This market is worth about one billion baht per 
year.  The blending factory can serve no t only the domestic market but the whole of

 The blending operation could  also apply for promotional incentives from the

following incentive package to promoted companies:   
1. Exemption of import duty on machinery, regardless of zone (location); 
2. Eight-year corporate income tax exem ption, regardless of zone (location); 
3. Other relevant location-based incentives. 
 2.2 Retail Bakery Franchising 
The success of retail chains in Thailand’s bakery landscape cannot be overemphasized.  
From homegrown entrepreneurs (e.g., S&P, Co ffee Beans by Dao, Little Home Bakery) to 
regional players (e.g., BreadTalk, Secret Recipe)  and global investors (e.g., Au Bon Pain, 
Mr. Donut, Dunkin’ Donuts), avid consumers coul d not seem to have enough of them – 
always excited to try new sweet and savory cr eations, anytime, anywhere.  The business is 
worth more than 9 billion baht per year and sti ll growing.  In fact, retail bakery chains 
are the fastest growing segment in Thailand’s bakery sector today. 
 Krispy Kreme, the donut franchise from the U.S., is the most recent franchise operator that entered Thailand’s bakery industry in 2010.  Sales in 2011 registered more than 
three-fold increase over the init ial year of operation; whereas  net profit grew more than 
four times.  At present Krispy Kreme has seve n stores in Bangkok, and has plans to open 
more branches each year – in line with the parent company’s global strategy to nearly 
double the number of international stores from 460 to 900 by the year 2017.    
 Why is this strategy working?    
 
“You give credit to the brand. Where we go people  are lined up to be there. It’s amazing. You 
wouldn’t think Thailand would even be aware of  it, but for many weeks there was always a line 
at that shop. When you look at the potential in  places like China and India, it’s pretty enormous. 
It’s kind of exciting to see that even though it’s the biggest part of who we are, it’s nowhere near 
a mature stage. There are years and years of growth out there for us.”  
Jim Morgan 
CEO, Krispy Kreme Doughnut Corp.

PAGE 89 Thus there are opportunities galore for retail fr anchising.  But as in any kind of business, 
for every opportunity there comes risk.  Some  pointers in a successful retail operation 
include:   
‒ First and foremost, the key is location, locat ion, location!  A retail franchise is 
driven by solid, consistent traffic.  Chose n locations or territories should support a 
retail franchise.  Some competition is fine, but not too much.  
‒ Second aspect is smart choice of bakery delights.  It is great to be creative and 
innovative, but Thais generall y would not like the taste of licorice in their bread or 
pastry!  A survey of consumer taste s and preferences would be useful. 
 
‒ Another important aspect is the employment fa ctor.  There is a need to hire, train 
and retrain – as well as lay-off employees  that underperform.  Human resources 
are a big part of operating retail franchis e concept, and becomes even more as the 
franchise expands to operate multiple locations.  Finding and keeping quality and 
loyal employees can be a challenge – es pecially in cosmopolitan Bangkok where 
the younger set, while eager to learn, can be also swayed easily by the ‘greener 
pasture at the other side of the fence.’   
 We expect the Thai market to be receptive fo r typical Dutch franchise concepts like ‘het 
Stoepje,’ ‘Bakker Bart’ and others. 
 2.3 Regional Operating Headquarters  
Dubbed the gateway to Asia, Thailand is in the best position for global companies to set up their Regional Operating Headquarters (ROH).  Compared with Singapore and Hong 
Kong, the cost of doing business in Thailand is still much cheaper; besides the kingdom 
offers equally modern, if not more advanced, infrastructure and reasonably skilled labor 
force.  Moreover, the Board of Investment of fers attractive tax incentive package to 
promoted ROH.  For example, MNCs such as DSM Food Specialt ies could consider relocating their ROH to 
Thailand.  
 
2.4  Technical cooperation 
The Netherlands is one of the world’s largest agricultural exporters and this is an area 
with opportunities for closer co-operation wi th Thailand because the country is strongly 
dependent on food exports and can take ad vantage of Dutch expertise and technical 
cooperation. Food processing, packaging, food control a nd logistics are all important 
areas for possible future cooperation.  This could well be extended to the bakery industry 
which is constantly looking for innovative and creative products to attract a huge 
customer base.  
 
For these kinds of cooperation, the Dutch go vernment provides subsidies to both Dutch 
company and its local (Thai) partner.  Annex 5 provides brief description of various 
subsidy programmes provided by the Dutch go vernment, e.g., Partners for International 
Business,  Matchmaking Facility, Private Sector Investment Program (PSI), Fund for 
Dutch Enterprises (FOM) and others.

INFLUENCING CONSUMPTION BAKERY PRODUCT IN

THANAPOTIVIRAT Pornnapa

Rajamangala University of Technology Thanayaburi, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract:
The aim of research was to study consumer buying behavior for bakery products in 
Thailand and to investigated the effect of marketing and socio-psychogical factor on the 
consumption bakery product in Thailand. Population of the research was the consumer who 
consume the barkery within 400 samples. The researchers obtained questionaire in Pathumwan 
District, Sathorn District, Silom District, Bang Rak District, which is an economic district and has 
a variety of snack shops and bakery shops. The data analyze was applied by percentage, mean, 
and standard deviation. To test the research hypotheses, Multiple Regression statistics was 
used. The results showed that marketing and socio-psychogical factor influenced consumer 
behaviors for bakery products in Thailand within significant at the 0.05 level.
Key words: bakery, marketing, consumption, socio-psychogical
1. Introduction
Nowadays, bakery products, although they are expensive, are very popular 
with the masses. For this reason, bakery products are growing in popularity in the 
confectionery market. Bakery products including biscuit, cake, pastry, flatbread, tortilla, 
chapati, bread, croissants, etc. (Collins, 2020; Snack and bakery, 2020; Samuel, 
2020). Asia Food Industry shown the report that snack is a traditional lifestyle habit for 
younger consumers, there has been changed in the recent years (Asia Food Industry, 
2020). According to American Baker Association (ABA), It was found that about 70% of 
customer was looking for different category of baked products especially for breakfast 
such as bread for lunch time and crackers for snack (ABA, 2019; Kristine Sherred, 
2019; Saurabh and Medha, 2017).

2.2.Consumer Buying Behavior
As Blackwell, Miniard and Engal (2013) said consumer behaviour consists of 
the activities that consumers receive and are offered, products and services.
In the business sector, the bakery is one of the largest in the industry. It 
comprises about 63,000 companies with approximately 41.5 million consumers in 2014 
(ITPC, 2015), which is considered a food business. In addition, the environment of 
competition becomes more intense every day due to the market expansion. There are 
various competitors such as convenience store, supermarkets, coffee shops, traditional 
stores, bars, and more. However, more demand for food consumers (Gustavo, Viviane,

develop improvement processes. Because it leads to diversity of consumer behaviour

evaluation of post-consumer and disposal stages.

- 261 -3. Methodology
This study was a cross-sectional study that used the survey method.
Population of the research was the consumer who consume the barkery. According to 
populations, approximately 385 samples for incomplete data or invalid surveys, 400 
samples were assigned in this research. The samples were calculated by using an 
error margin at 5% and confidence interval levels at 95%. The researchers obtained
questionaire within four areas based on the economic center in Bangkok which 
including Bang Rak, Silom, Pathumwan, Sathorn, Bangkok. (Culture Trips, 2020; Fresh 
Property, 2017; Bangkok Post, 2018; Thailandguru, 2018). The reason for selecting 
these areas due to there are many rental building offices well known organizations, 
and is also full of working people. moreover there are variety of restaurants around. 
The survey had done by a trained enumerator in order to ensure the quality of 
the data collection. It was completed a survey each respondent as guided by a 
questionnaire. A questionnaire was complete when respondents had answered all the 
questions or refuse their participation from these. The survey was collected from May 
August 2020 and entered to a statistic program. The researcher calculated a total of 
400 samples, and the samples were collected using the Multi-stage Sampling method 
as the following:
Step 1: we selected by using Purposive Sampling which selected four areas 
which were Bang Rak, Silom, Pathumwan and Sathorn, Bangkok where there are 
variety of restaurants and shops.
Step 2: we randomly sourced the name of restaurants and shops from 
Department of Business Development (Department of Business Development, 2020)
Step 3: we selected 20 shop and restaurants and collected data form each 
restaurant within 40 cases. 
Step 4: we collected the data by using the probability methods which collect in 
3 period time as 1) 08.00 10.00 A.M. 2) 12.00 A.M. 14.00 P.M. and 3) 5.00 7.00 
P.M. 
The data was collected by structured questionnaires separated into five 
sections as the followings  1) the information about  respondents demographics 
including 6 questions about  gender, age, marital status, education level,  income, and 
occupation; 2) consumers behaviour in bakery products including 6 questions which 
expenses, favorites in bakery products, information in bakery products, place to buy,  
reason of buying, and frequency of buying; 3) the questions about factors including 
socio-psychogical factor, marketing mix, and decision making. 
The socio-psychogical factor of respondents were classified into three 
categories: activities, interest, opinions. Each of question was asking agreement with 
five level form Likert scale number from 1 to 5 (strongly disagree - strongly agree).
The marketing mix were classified into 7 categories as: 1) product; 2) price; 3) 
place; 4) promotion; 5) people; 6) process, and 7) physical evidence. Each of question 
was asking agreement with five level form Likert rating scale number from 1 to 5 
(strongly disagree - strongly agree).

Studies in Business and Economics no. 17(1)/2022
- 262 -The dependent variable is the decision making, were classified into five 
categories: problem recognition, information search, evaluation of alternative, purchase 
decision, post purchase behaviour. Each of question was asking agreement with five 
level of Likert Scale number from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).
For testing an instrument, a questionnaire was pretested with 30 samples were 
similar to the population in order to clarity of the lang
mean that the reliability of questionnaire was acceptable.
The content of questionnaire was also validated by five experts, including 
owners and academics. The test contained 65 items and had an acceptable measure 
of content validity; the index of conjugate (IOC) was 0.96.
The statistics were describing the variables by presenting the frequency, 
percentage, mean, and standard deviation for personal characteristic, consumers 
behaviour in bakery products, lifestyle pattern, marketing mix and decision making.  
This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) in 
Rajamangala University of Technology, Phatum Thani as RMUTT No. Exp 04/63
The research framework applied socio-psychogical factor by using the AIO and 
Values and Lifestyles (VALS) Theory. The model is used to describe lifestyle pattern, 
the perspective of consumer behaviour as socio-psychogical factor influencing 
consumer behaviour. There are different consumption habits about product or services. 
In addition, the main idea of VALS Theory show the systems that classify consumers 
based on their values and lifestyle pattern. The researchers used the preliminary data 
from personality and psychology for analyzing the consumer about purchasing decision 
(WILL, 2017; Hitesh, 2018; Aditya and Reza, 2017)
As the hypothesis testing, the study was using multiple linear regression. In 
addition, this method is suitable for predicting the effects of independent variables on 
period scale variables. Multiple linear regression such as normal distribution, 
multidimensional distribution, elasticity resilience, auto-correlation are satisfied at the 
lowest point. Multiple linear regression is performed using a statistical programmer. 
Additionally, the results are considered statistically significant if the p-value is <0.05.

purchasing decision (r-square=0.459)

6. Finding and discussion
Consumer buying behaviour mention to the selection, purchase and consumption 
of goods or service for their satisfaction. There is different process connected to consumer 
behaviour. Some factors, have specific characters influencing in their decision-making
process, shopping habits, brands and so forth. Therefore, it can be separated with socio-
psychogical factor as the following:
Regarding to socio-psychogical factor within activities had impact significantly with 
purchasing decision. Due to the consumers eating habits, the most important factors 
affecting the consumption of bakery products. The survey found that the most important 
factor concern with activities was marketing mix and purchasing decision of bakery 
products. They can be attached of rawness and smell of bakery products, perception of the 
reasonable price, sensory such as taste which it also be due to the fact that bakery 
products that consumer is used to consume every day.  Moreover, the product lover can 
be change by reason of social factors. The most important personal factors, influencing the 
buyer behaviour such as age, occupation income and lifestyle pattern. (Lubica, Kristina, 
Zdenka, and Ingrida, 2020; Ching, Chin, Ming and Wan, 2019; Kavitha, Souji, Prabhu, 
2011). According to the study, they were consisted of activities that consumers receive and 
are offered, products and services (Blackwell, Miniard, and Engal, 2013). Similarly, the 
study with Hes (2009) was noticed that the factors to purchasing bakery products is

Studies in Business and Economics no. 17(1)/2022
- 268 -   products quality and perception which including sensory, health and food safety (Stávková, 
consumers are attracted to higher nutritiona of bakery products like whole grain bread. 
(Golian et al., 2018; Adam, Hiamey, and Afenyo, 2014). In addition, consumers are also 
attracted to higher nutritional bakery products. Furthermore, the research of Nagyová et al. 
(2012) said that consumers can perceive quality on the basis of other factors such as 
appearance, color and flavor of bakery products. The Most consumers, influence factor is 
price (Kubicová and Kádeková, 2011), especially the luxury pastries.
Moreover, socio-psychogical factor within Interest had impact significantly with 
purchasing decision. According to the characteristic of consumers based on their lifestyle, 
which can be used to differentiable bakery product form competitors offering, infrastructure 
or market segment. Consumers are influenced by people around, looking for the 
information from people or social media factor influencing consumer such as family, 
reference group, roles and status., developing technology and changing living conditions, 
changing in consumer behaviour. Therefore, manufacturing always show varieties of 
products, offering specific products to their consumers (Gustavo, Viviane, Luiz, and 
Recebido, 2016; Kristen, 2011; Ramya & S.A. Mohamed, 2016; Hulya, Fidan, Mevlut, 
Metin, 2017). Similarly, the study of Horská et al. (2009) said consumer behaviour, 
satisfaction or efficiency. Consumer behaviour are characterized by carefully, awareness, 
experience, and evaluation of alternatives (Rovný et al., 2010). Also, the model developed 
by Blackwell, Miniard and Engel (2013) illustrate the purchase decision processes as the 
following stages: 1) recognition of need, 2) information search process, 3) evaluation of 
purchase; 4) purchase; 5) consumption, 6) evaluation of post-consumer and disposal 
stages. In addition, there is a relatively high impulse and emotional state when purchasing
bakery products are influenced by a number of factors such as cultural, social, and 
psychological factors. (Géci, Nagyová, and Rybanská, 2017)
Furthermore, socio-psychogical factor within Opinion had impact significantly with 
purchasing decision. Marketing segmentation were classified consumers through a 
merchandise mix that meets their lover for products which is understanding of consumer 
behaviour.  In addition, it related with social and condition of bakery products which is 
assist grocers, food retailer and service operation to meeting consumer for specific 
product. Moreover, price is the most important factor influencing because some consumers 
do not have stable income. The place in marketing mix is also convincing them to buy 
bakery product which are available in supermarkets, bakery shop and so forth. 
Additionally, the bakery products it has alternative forms for sale, such as in fast food.
Therefore, the bakery store needs to improve their marketing mix, and also have to 
focus on the lacking areas which they need to apply the marketing mix on their bakery 
store in order to get more attraction and recognition by the consumers. Feedback from 
consumers is also important in order to enhance their performance and product quality 
(Ching, Chin, Ming and Wan, 2019; Kavitha, Souji, Prabhu, 2011; Abdullah, Ahmad, Nural, 
Ahmad, Nur, & Mohd, 2019). Also, the study related with the model, developing by 
Blackwell, Miniard and Engel (2013) presented the purchase decision processes.

ABST
RACT : Application of Means End 
Chain Theory by using laddering technique of 
interview was used to bring out consumer 
behavior through the interview. The aims of 
this project were to apply Means End Chain 
technique to food service study in case study of 
bakery restaurant service and to find major 
attributes that influencing bakery restaurant 
selection of people in Bangkok. Hierarchical 
value maps were constructed by consumer 
data. From 100 consumers, a hierarchical value 
map shown that major attributes for selecting 
bakery sh op were “Atmosphere”, “Meeting 
point”, “Convenient”, “Pass by”, “Delicious”, 
“Interesting product” and “For giving”. For the 
consequences were “Have more time”, 
“Feeling relax”, “Sharing experience”, “Save money”, “Want to come again” and “Qual ity 
work”. The value that consumer mostly got 
were “Being happy” and “Satisfied”. 
Moreover, a hierarchical value map of “Sit in 
bakery shop ” from 50 consumers shown that 
the attributes of “Feeling relax” and “Quality 
work” were main reasons to select “Sit in 
bakery shops ”. The value that “Sit in bakery 
shop ” were select ed was “Being happy”. From 
consideri ng a hierarchical value map of “T ake 
away bakery shops ” from 50 consumers, 
shown the attribute of selected “Take away  
bakery shop ” was “Convenient”. The 
consequence related to “C onvenient ” attribute 
was “Have more time to do the quality work” 
and then this consequence also related to the 
value of “Being happy”. The attr ibute of 
selected bakery shop from 57 employed 
consumers was “Convenient”. The 
consequence of convenient was “Have more 
time to do the quality work” and t he value was 
“Being happy” also, while t he attributes of 43 
unemployed consumers were “Want to try new 
product” and “Made of feeling excited”. The 
value of selected bakery shop by unemployed 
was “Being happy”. Results from this research 
showed that the different group of consumer 
showed different profiles of hierarchical value 
maps. Bakery shop owners should concern 
about the convenience and the atmosphere of 
the shop to attract consumer.  They should 
provide the space for meeting of the customer. 
The interesting and delicious products will 
attract to the consumer. Providing the product 
for giving as a gift would help increasing 
customers.

behavior, Bakery shop 
INTRODUCTION 
296

The 20th Food Innovation Asia Conference 2018 (FIAC 2018)

14-16 June 2018
Nowadays, the lifetime of human was 
changing from the past. Our world develops 
very fast and the competition are applied in 
every things. Food business was one of the 
most competition that grows very fast because 
human consume food every day.  Bakery 
product is the most food that human consumes 
every day and they are many types of bakery 
product launched to our world. There are many 
bakery shops in Thailand for customers to 
choose when visiting. Every bakery shops try 
to make their shop unique from the other shops 
to attract customers. There are many factors 
that people use for selecting bakery shop such 
as review form the internet or the taste of the 
food.    
Means End Chain theory (MEC) was applied 
by using the laddering technique of interview 
that rarely used in Thailand. Because Means 
End Chain must take long time to collect data 
in one consumer. To ensure that the answer 
from the consumer was exactly what they want 
to answer and also to know the real feeling 
when they answer the questions.  
The aims of this research were to apply Means 
End Chain technique to the food service study 
in a case study of bakery restaurant service and 
to find the most famous attributes that 
influencing bakery shop selection of people in 
Bangkok. 
Means End Chain Theory  
Means 
end chain theory is a marketing 
research technique used when the researcher 
generally tries to probe the mind of the 
customer to bring out the distinctions of 
consumer behavior. It is a combination of both 
qualitative and quantitative research methods 
to bring out the latent need of the customers 
(Figure1). The researchers are highly qualified 
and trained to take the interviews and bring out the attributes that customer value whil e 
ordering or selecting the product or service.  
Figure 1  Value chain for Means End Chain 
Theory 
(Source : http://www.mbaskool.com/business-
concepts/marketing-and -strategy-terms/16560-
mean-end -chain-theory.html ) 
Means End Chain was the technique that can 
bring out all the things that happen during the 
time that consumer consume product or using 
service. It can be feeling, taste, emotional or 
anything that consumer can imagine. Means 
End Chain gave the freedom for consumer to 
think by their own and the information that 
came out will be the original consumer insight. 
Means End Chain technique in Foodservice 
In 2013, Tengpongsathon and others found that 
the application of Means -End Chain theory for 
studying consumer  attitude  on green tea 
beverages was conducted.  The 60 consumers  
were interviewed by laddering interview 
technique to generate green tea beverage 
qualities.  The result from hierarchical value  
maps showed 3 groups of green tea qualities 
(attribute, consequence and value).  After that 
297

The 20th Food Innovation Asia Conference 2018 (FIAC 2018) 
Creative Food for Future and Sustainability 
14-16 June 2018
the 30 selected  attributes  were  used  as  
major  attributes  in  a  standard  questionnaire  
using  Check- All-That-Apply technique  for  
studying  consumer  (n=100)  attitudes.  The 
consumer data was analyzed with 
correspondence analysis and was construc ted 
to be corresponding  maps. It was found that 
they had positive attitudes on  chrysanthemum 
taste of green tea because of healthy, relaxing 
and refreshing attributes but had negative 
attitudes on original taste of green tea because 
of bitter, dislike and turbid attributes.  
Previous research showed that the most 
important factor determining whether a 
customer will r eturn to the restaurant was the 
quality of food; the least considered factors 
were place and ambiance of restaurant 
(Brumback, 1998; Soriano, 2002; Sulek & 
Hensley, 2004).   
From all of the data that was found, it was 
shown the importance of the bakery sho p 
service. The bakery shop service was chosen 
for study the consumer insight in this research.  
The laddering technique for study the bakery 
shop consumer was means end chain theory 
because of the data that collecting directly 
from the consumer.    
MATE
RIAL S AND METHODS  
Th
e selection of the participant  
The participants (n=100) were the bakery shop 
consumers that have been visiting ba kery shop.  
Participants were  classified into two groups 
which were  “Sit in bakery shop consumer” 
(n=50) and “Take away bakery shop 
consumer” (n=50).  Al l the participants were 
also classified by employment  status . Th
e process of collecting data   
Using 
the means end chain technique to collect 
data by asking the question about the attribute, 
the consequence and the value of bakery shop 
services. Participants got the interview one b y 
one and every question was related to the 
answer for the previous question. First 
question for every participant would be “Have 
you ever visited the bakery s hop?” and the next 
question depend ed on the answer from the first 
question. The interview continued  until the 
participant can give the answer about the 
product attribute which is the characteristic 
that consumer used for describe the product or 
service (What is product?), the consequence 
which is the effect of the attribute (What does 
the product deliver to the consumer) and  the 
value that they achieve from using the service 
(What does the product aid the consumer in 
doing?) (Cole, 2010).   
Examples of the interview 
Interviewer: Have you ever visited the bakery 
shop? 
Participant: Yes,  I like bakery products. 
Interviewer: Why you like bakery products? 
Participant : Because it’s convenient . 
Interviewer: How convenient is important to 
you? 
Participant: I will have more time for working. 
Interviewer: How have more time for working 
affect to you? 
Participant: Will get the better result.

result will classify into 3 parts (Table 1)

The hierarchical value map was the main 
output from adding consumer data into the 
LadderUX program to show the major results 
from a laddering study of a group of 
participants without going through all the 
individual ladder. Cut-off level (10 %) was 
used to reducing the complexity of the map.

CONCLUSIONS 
From 
100 consumers showed the different of 
consumer insights and consumer behaviors. 
Then, in order to meet the demands of each 
consumer groups, every bakery shop owners 
should concern about every consumer 
behaviors or at least the attributes that  
important and can be easily to develop. 
Moreover, bakery shop owners should also 
concern about the convenience and the 
atmosphere of the ir shops to attract consumer.  
They should provide the space for meeting of 
the customer. The interesting and delicious 
products will attract to the consumer. 
Providing the product for giving as a gift 
would help increasing customer. 
To improve the laddering technique, before 
making the interview, the information of the 
product or service must be the same with every 
participant. To reduce the variation of the

Development of Healthy Snack Bar 
from Germinated Sweet C orn 
Khanittha Wiriya1, Khaunjira Losirikul1 
and Chutamat Niwat1* 
1Food Technology Program, School of Agro -
Industry, Mae Fah Luang University, 
Chiang Rai 57100, Thailand .  
*Corresponding author :
chutamat@mfu .ac.th
ABSTRACT : With an increasing awareness 
among consumers on healthy eating, healthy 
snack bars have become immensely popular . 
Sweet corn is a great source of thiamin, 
folate, vitamin C, phosphorous, manganese, 
and fiber . Germination is a process to 
increase the nutritive value, especially 
gamma -aminobutyric acid (GABA ) . 
Therefore, this study aimed to develop sn ack 
bars from the germinated sweet corn . The 
experimental design by Mixture Design was 
used, and seven snack bars formulas 
containing 50 -70% germinated sweet corn, 
20-40% black sesame, 10 -30% pumpkin
seed, 25 % oat, and 20 % honey were
investigated for physi cal (hardness and
color ), chemical (proximate analysis, GABA
and antioxidant activity (DPPH assay ),
microbiological properties (total plate count
and yeast and mold ) and sensory evaluation
using 9 point hedonic scale . The results
indicated that the hardnes s of snack bar
increased when an addition of germinated
sweet corn, black sesame and pumpkin seed
increased (P<0.05) .  Lightness (L* )
significantly decreased when black sesame
increased (P<0.05), whereas redness (a* )
significantly decreased when pumpkin see d
increased (P<0.05) . In addition, yellowness
(b*) significantly increased when germinated
sweet corn increased (P<0.05) .  The
proximate composition in term of 
carbohydrate and moisture content 
significantly increased when germinated sweet corn increased (P<0.05), while fat 
significantly increased with the addition of 
black sesame and protein content 
significantly increased with the addition of 
pumpkin seed (P<0.05). However, there were 
no significant difference in sugar and crude 
fiber in all samples (P>0.05) .  In addition, 
GABA content considerably increased when 
a proportion of germinated sweet corn 
increased in the formula (P<0.05) .  The 
results also exhibited that total plate count 
and yeast and mold of all samples was less 
than 25 and 10 CFU /g, respective ly. 
Furthermore, sensory evaluation by 30 
untrained panelists showed no significant 
difference in overall attribute in formula 2, 7, 
3 and 6 (P>0.05). In conclusion, the formula 
6 which consisted of 33 % germinated sweet 
corn, 11 % black sesame 11 % pumpkin s eed, 
25% oat and 20 % honey contained 2 .53±0 .00 
mg/g d.b. GABA, 3 .85±0 .06 mol Trolox 
equivalent /g d.b. antioxidant activity and 
received overall preference score 
(6.03±1 .35). This formula could be used for 
further development of healthy snack bar 
from germ inated sweet corn . 
Keyword s: Gamma -aminobutyric acid, 
Germination, Snack bar, Sweet corn  
INTRODUCTION  
Health and wellness is a trend observed 
throughout ready -to-eat snack bar . Snack 
bars are nutritious food composed of several 
ingredients including cereals, fruits, nuts and 
sugar among other . In the year 2015, Chiang 
Rai province has a yield of 65,848 ton s of 
sweet corn harvest per

province has a yield of 65,848 ton s of 
sweet corn harvest per year [1], which is 
considered the highest amount of output 
compared to the annual yield of other 
provinces . Cereals are an important form of 
human diet because they provide starch and 
carbohydrate including dietary and fiber . 
Maize (Zea mays  L.), commonly known as 
corn, is the cereal with the highest production 
worldwide after wheat and rice [2]. Corn is 
303

The 20th Food Innovation Asia Conference 201 8 (FIAC 201 8) 
Creative Food for Future and Sustainability  
14-16 June 201 8
essential source of vitamins thiamin, 
riboflavin, niacin, pantothenic acid, vitamin 
B6, and folate [3].  
Germination is a pr ocess to  increase the 
nutritive value such as peptides, sugars, 
amino acids, and especially gamma -
aminobutyric acid (GABA ). GABA is 
produced by the decarboxylation of L -
glutamic acid that contains a four carbon 
amino acid . GABA is provided many 
beneficial effects for human health such as an 
inhibitory neurotransmitter in the 
sympathetic nervous system, controlling 
stress and decreasing blood pressure  [4]. 
Germinated cereal grains , such as barley, rice 
and soybean,  have been widely studied for 
GABA production [5]. Thao and Niwat [6] 
showed that the germination of colored rice 
at pH 6 significantly increased GABA, total 
phenolic contents and antioxidants activities 
of germinated rice compared to non-
germinated rice .   
Sesame (Sesamum indicum  L.) has high 
nutritional value due to the significant 
amounts of dietary fiber, protein, natural 
antioxidants, unsaturated fatty acids, 
vitamins, and mineral constituents present in 
its composition . The chemical composition of 
sesame seed shows 58 % oil, 2 5% protein, 
13.5% carbohydrate and 5 % ash [7]. The 
lipid fraction of sesame seeds shows good 
oxidative stability, which is contributed from  
the essential fatty acids (e.g. oleic, linoleic, 
and arachidonic  acid) present in its 
composition, as well as antiox idant 
compounds (e.g., sesamin, sesamolin, and 
sesamol ) [8].  
The main component in pumpkin seed is a 
lipid, approximately 51 %. Pumpkin seed oil 
is rich in unsaturated fatty acids including 
linoleic acid (55.6% of total lipid ) and oleic 
acid (20.4% of total lipid ). Pumpkin seed oil 
has been produced worldwide due to h igh 
nutritional effects for human health [9]. 
Whole grain oats are a rich source of dietary 
fiber, micronutrients, and macronutrients . 
The health -promoting effects have been related to fiber and potentially to the abilities 
of other oat -derived components or factors in 
modulating oxidative stress, inflammator y 
stress, and glycemic response [10]. Dietary 
fiber in whole grain oat foods, especially β -
glucans, is a key component i n mitigating 
glycemic response . In addition to, oats are 
also rich sources of phen olics including 
flavonoids, phenolic acids, lignans, and 
avenanthramides (A VEs ) [11]. 
Honey is a rich source of carbohydrates, and 
used as a natural sweetener . In addition, 
honey is i mportant sour ce of other minor 
constituents  such as polyphenols, 
carotenoids, minerals, proteins, free amino 
acid, enzymes and vitamins [12]. Due to 
limitation of information and product from 
germinated sweet corn, therefore t he 
objectives of this study were 1 ) to develop 
snack bars from the germinated sweet corn, 
and 2 ) to investigate physical, chemical, 
microbiological properties and sensory 
evaluation of germinated sweet corn snack 
bar. This product could be increased value -
added to sweet corn and will be another 
option of healthy snack .  
MATERIAL S AND METHODS 
Materials  
Sweet corn (Zea mays  L. var saccharata ), 
black sesame, pumpkin seed, oat, and honey 
were purchased from the local store in 
Chiang Rai province, Thailand . They were

from the local store in 
Chiang Rai province, Thailand . They were 
stored at 4 °C until use . 
Chemical s 
Folin –Ciocalteu ’s phenol reagent was 
purcha sed from Fluka (Buchs, Switzerland ).  
Trolox ((±)-6-Hydroxy -2,5,7,8 -
tetramethylchromane -2-carboxylic acid ) and 
DPPH  (2,2-diphenyl -1-picryhydrazyl ) were 
purchased from Aldrich (Steinheim, 
Germany ). Potassium chloride, sodium 
acetate, anhydrous sodium carbo nate and 
304

The 20th Food Innovation Asia Conference 201 8 (FIAC 201 8) 
Creative Food for Future and Sustainability  
14-16 June 201 8
gamma -aminobutyric acid (GABA ) were 
purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, 
Germany ). Ferric chloride (FeCl 3) was 
purchased from Ajax Finechem (Seven Hills, 
Australia ). All other chemicals and solvents 
in this study were an analytical grade . 
Germinated preparation  
Germinated sweet corn preparation was 
modified from the method described by 
Kanyakam et al . [13] and Thao and Niwat 
[6]. Firstly, 100 grams of corn were sterilized 
with 0 .1% sodium hypochlorite solution (1:5 
w/v) for 30 min, and then rinsed wi th 
distilled water . Next, corn was soaked by 
distilled water with the corn -water ratio = 1:5 
(w/v) at 35C for 18 hours at pH 6 using 
citric acid . Soaked sweet corn was  rinsed 
with water  and placed in a plastic box 
covered with a lid and germinated at 37˚C for 
48 hours . Afterward, germinated sweet corn 
was heated by a tray dryer at 50˚C for 2 
hours to stop germination  and final moisture 
content below 15% was received .  
Experimental design  
Mixture design was used w ith different ratio 
of 50-70% germinated sweet corn, 20-40% 
black sesame, and 10-30% pumpkin seed . 
Honey and oat were fixed at 20 and 25 %, 
respectively . Then, 7 formulations of snack 
bar were shown in Table 1 .  
Snack bars processing  
Snack bars processing was modified from the 
method described by LaRue et al . [14] and 
Buakum and Lopphu, [15]. Firstly, 
germinated sweet corn was mixed with other 
ingredients  in a mixing bowl . After that, the 
mixture was transferred to a baking  pan that 
placed the parchment paper on the bottom . 
An extra sheet of parchment paper was used  
to press on top of the mixture to form  the bar 
shape with approximate 0.5 cm thickness . Then,  the mixture was  baked at 150˚C for 15 
minutes and cooled down on a rack . The 
snack was cut into 1 .5x3.0 cm2 piece  using a 
serrated knife . The snack bar was w rapped 
individually with plastic wrap and stored at 4 
˚C for further analysis .

Extraction 
All of the samples were carried out by the 
method described by Thao and Niwat [6]. 
Ground samples (1 g) were extracted with 15 
ml of 70 % methanol and covered with the 
aluminum foil at room temperature (28˚C ) 
for 12 hours, and then filtrated by filter 
papers (Whatman no .4). Extracts solution 
were then collected and used for further 
analysis . 
Texture profile analysis (TPA ) 
Texture will be determined by texture 
analyzer . 
Color measurement  
The color of snack bars was measured by a 
colorimeter (HunterLab, MiniScan EZ ) using 
the CIELAB system . Each sample  was 
ground using a blender and packed into a

small transparent  plastic bag . It was then 
folded in half and put in front of reflectance 
port.  
Proximate composition  
Chemical compositions (carbohydrate, 
protein, fat, crude fiber, ash content and 
moisture content ) of snack bars were carried 
out according to the procedure of AOAC  
[16].  
Water activity analysis  
Water activity will be determ ined by water 
activity analyzer (Novasina AWC500 ). 
Determination of GABA content 
GABA content was measured by 
spectrophotometry according to  the meth od 
described by Thao and Niwat [6] and GABA 
(0-1000 µg /ml) was used as a standard .  
Each extract sample (200 µl) was added to a 
test tube that contained 200 µl of 0 .2 M 
borate buffer pH 9 . 6% phenol (1 ml ) was 
added to each tube . Subsequently, the tubes 
were shaken and cooled in an ice bath for 5 
min. Next, 0 .4 ml of sodium hypochlorite 
(NaOCl ) was added to each  tube. The tubes 
were shaken again for 1 min and cooled in 
ice bath for 5 min, then incubated in boiling 
water bath for 10 min . After cooling the 
sample  to room temperature , the absorbance 
of each sample was evaluated against a blank 
at 630 nm . The GABA co ntent was expressed 
as mg GABA /100 g db samples .  
Determination of DPPH radical 
scavenging activity (DPPH assay ) 
The DPPH assay was determined according 
to the method of Molyneux [17] using Trolox 
(0-1000 µg /ml) as standard . Each extract 
sample (50 µl ) was mixed with 1 .95 ml 60 
µM DPPH solution and left in the dark place for 30 min at room temperature . The 
absorbance of the samples was measured at 
517 nm using methanol as blank . The 
calibration curve was plotted between Trolox 
concentration (µM) and % inhibition . The 
DPPH radical scavenging activity of the 
sample  was expressed as µmole TE / g db 
sample . 
Microbiological analysis  
Total plate count and  yeast and  mold of snack 
bar from germinated sweet corn were 
determined according to the procedures 
according to  AOAC  [16]. 
Sensory evaluation  
Taste, color, texture, appearance and overall 
acceptability of germinated sweet corn bar 
were assessed by 30 untrained panelists using 
a 9-point hedonic scale , which 1= extremely 
dislike, 5 = moderate ly liked and 9 = like 
extremely . 
Statistical analysis  
Data were expressed as means ± standard 
deviation . All experiments conducted in this 
study were performed in triplicate . The 
general linear model procedure of the 
Statistical Analysis System (SPSS, version 
16)was used for data analysis . Ducan ’s test
was conducted to compare mean at 5 %
significance (P<0.05).
